reasoning: The critique targets an important premise used in the paper’s case that unbounded linear views are “fussy”: that value-per-unit-resource is fat-tailed, so near-optimal outcomes require aiming at a very specific use of resources. If that empirical claim failed, that specific route to “linear views are fussy” would weaken. However, it’s only one strand of a broader ‘no easy eutopia’ case (other strands include multiplicative/fragility arguments and the bounded-views analysis), so centrality is moderate rather than high. The critique’s refutation power is limited: it mainly notes under-justification/contestability and gestures at diminishing returns, without engaging the paper’s supporting considerations (e.g., theoretical arguments for log returns, value-efficiency reasoning, experience-intensity evidence), so it weakens rather than overturns the targeted claim. Most statements are plausible: it’s genuinely non-obvious that intrinsic goods follow fat tails, and a flatter top would make the target less narrow; thus correctness is fairly high. It is focused, clear, and contains little to no extraneous material.
title: The fat-tailed value distribution claim lacks support for intrinsic goods
